Warwick Sept 19th 1853
My Dear Children,
I receiv'd your letter today I feel very sorry you cannot conveniently come--But cheifly on your own account--I don't know as it would be consistent for you to leave home if it was I think you would enjoy it and that it would do you good--I think I can go home alone without any difficulty and I rather think that I shall start for home in about ten days from now
I am now at the good old family mansion where I was born & brought up & O how familiar and dear every spot seems to me the great rock the garden the Orchard the great walnut trees & every foot of ground where my little bare feet us'd to run I suppose there is no better pasture land about & yet it appears to me that one half of the surface of the great east pasture here is bare rock & yet this Farm was pric'd at 1930!! & the mountain lot 320! about 8, an acre for the mountain pasture!!
Maria & her mother live here alone except she hires a man a part of the time. She buys & sells cattle 7 horses etc. & carries on all her farming business with as much judgement & discretion as a man as far as I can see She bought her a Horse not long since & this morning she sold 3 cattle Sister Hannah tho' she's a little delicate old feeble looking woman does most of the house work making butter etc. and she braided hats enough last year to come to 30 dollars!!
Completed

It beats  all how painfully economical & industrious people are here.  Everything looks just about exactly as it did forty years ago except that the rich have grown richer & the poor have disappeared.  The large fish have cut up the small ones - Bet you can't think how lonely it seems at the house without Brother Joseph.  I can't be content to stay here many day.  I have concluded not to go to Dunbarton & don't think I shall go to Royalston so it is possible that I may be at home at Bangor by about the first of Oct.  If it is convenient shall go to Milo in a week or two after.  Tell Charlie I am very glad indeed that he has learn'd all that hymn hope he will say it over often so as not to forget & I suppose Jane will help him think of it & try to learn him all she can.  I hope & expect that she has become a good industrious patient girl and is a great comfort to you all - I thought before I come away that she was trying to do well & we know that she can if she tries be a very capable, good girl.
May God be with you, & bless you and guide you in all your ways from your affectionate Mother.
I intended to send this by the last mail but we have had a very rainy time for several days, & Maria had nobody to send.  I don't know but what if I could know that you could conveniently come in a fortnight from now I should wait - but tis so uncertain - I think I had better be getting home and after I get home & you get your Harvesting done you had better take a trip somewhere perhaps to N.York - or you can come here if I am gone home & you'll find plenty of peaches & chestnuts.
Completed

Cedar Grove Milo Feb 11th 1854
My Dear Son, I return here yesterday Eliab came up with me and has gone back this afternoon -- received letters from Isaac and Antoinette last tuesday I was very much amus'd at the account of Sam'l's arrival at there I hope he will enjoy himself & do well & you likewise. Sam'l must have had rather a hard time getting out there I want very much to hear more about him how he left his family & etc. Sister Conant wrote me that your uncle Conant had made his Will given Sam'l 50 dollars and  Hervey all the rest it is too bad I think but he is of one mind I really think that he means to do just right & thinks he does in so doing His father gave him all after fixing of 3 daughters & himself & wife were sick a great while so that all was very little, & he of course thought he must do as his father did Why don't you write more particularly about
(left margin) have you or has he any idea that you should ever like that part of the country for a permanent residence
(upper margin) Tell Sam'l Conant I should be very glad if he would write to me and tell how he likes there & what he thinks of Isaac & you and all the suckers out there He looks rather deep into things I should value his opinion & judgement in many things very highly
Completed

what you are doing how you like your work & how you like the country how Sam's like & what he is doing - I am a little afraid you don't like as well as you expected tell me about it & whether Sam'l is disappointed.  I want to know all about how you feel-what you think & whether you are glad you went there.  Eliab did not feel willing I should come up in the stage thought I could come more comfortably with him but it cost him some for he broke his sleigh thills which with his house hire would be six or seven dollars I suppose - Mr R R Harkin, is almost gone in consumption is not expected to live many days I fear that they are going to be rather hard with Eliab  he thinks they ought to give him more because he has had all the work to do as Mr H has been so sick all the time.  They don't seem inclin’d to but perhaps they'll do what is right - bye and bye.  He has met with quite a loss again on the Brig Susan Duncan.  Percie has had another attack of the croup not so bad as before the little fellow has been wrong'd by being kept in a warm room so continually - has never been suffer'd to snuff the out door air half as much as he ought
Completed

I suppose Albina keeps you "posted up" in regard to things about home - I found Josie pretty sick but evidently getting better weak feverish & fretful, but has considerable appetite.  He coughs some yet but I think he will be pretty smart in a few days - Charlie is pretty well look more healthy and is more fleshy than when I went away.  Little Mary has some cold & is cutting teeth.  She is too spunky to be sick - but she is on the whole rather pleasanter than she was last fall.  Uncle Mark has gone as suppose you know & James does the chores at the barn probably they are not done just as you would do but I guess he is pretty faithful.  We have had a long spell of very cold weather - Mercury down to 30 below zero some days - which has made it hard for James, & the creatures at the barn too suppose our barn is abominably cold - The school has but two week more to keep - them James can get along well enough if his folks will let him play but Mr. Rider will think he can earn considerable at home - He is more manly & steady than he was a year or two ago but he is a boy yet.
Completed

Sabbath eve I have been up to Mr Sargents today he & his wife were both in one bed sick.  He is very sick with lung fever, she has neuralgia in her head, Mrs. Dales was there & some other neighbors came in, & got up another bed & mov'd the cookstove out into the kitchen & put our open stove, that you left in wood closet, up in their room, & Mrs Dolen is going to stay and take care of them - it has been rather sickly about here some cases of scarlet fever in the first part of winter - & measles at the village.  Colds & coughs in abundance all about.  Tis a cold, hard, rough, country here, - I suspect that James feels a little anxiety about whether he is to have pay & how much, I've been thinking & would wish to his Father & Mother & see what they think would be right - I don't see but we must keep him if we can can at whatever price - for it is next to impossible to get a man or boy to do anything -  it is rather hard times for poor folks I suppose, every think is so high corn 1,30 oats, 75' flour 11, or 12,00 - wood in Bangor 5, to 6,5'0 - we are burning here green white birch - however the school will soon be done and the weather will be warmer & we will all get along nicely - no not nicely, but comfortably, tolerably can we, or had me better try to do anything about getting the house paintd, paper'd before Mr DeWitt comes - Shall you be home soon enough to do it they have not said when they should come but suppose in May or first June - a great deal of love to Isaac & Antoinette & the Dear little D. Mayo.  Can you make it worth while for you to stay during the spring if I probably the work can be done some way if it is best write, write
Completed

Cedar Grove, Milo, March 19th 1854

Albina is writing so I must just say a word to tell you we are well and liking to "spring out" nicely.  Sam'l says the snow was all of 5'feet deep in the roads till 2 days of warm weather in the last week settled it some - but yesterday it snow'd & blow'd again today the roads are blocked up with hard drifts.
Charlie is learning to read some but it requires all the coaxing strategies I can muster to keep up our interest in it somedays he seems very much engag'd & then again it is hard work - He can, read off favourably well in two syllables and in reading words of 3 or 4 letters.
He waits up on the table when there is no other man here with considerable grace & dignity - took it up of his own hand - & insist upon the privilege with some pertinuaty ever since James went away he has split up his kindling wood at night & got up & built the fire - with being told.
Those warm days he was marching round on the snowdrifts on a pr of wooden snow shoes that Sumner & he rigg'd up - Joseph got well very quick after he was sick.  He eats very hearty & his cheeks really stick out he is so fat now.  Little Mary does not talk but can make herself understood, is very old for her age, sits up in her dinner chair & feeds herself at table.
[at top upside down] Much love to Isaac & Antoinette and the little Du Coign Mayo How I do want to see the little fellow & all the rest of you.
Completed

you say you & others are building a house who is your master work man or don't you have any in two or three of your last letters you have not mention'd S Conant.  I am very much interested to know all about what kind of a man he is & how he is prospering.
What do you read or don't you have time to read much of anything - on the whole are you getting to be a more perfect man for going out there of course you are gaining some knowledge whether it is the most useful knowledge for you is another question.  However that may be I trust you are doing some good to yourself & others.  Maj. Furber was married last month to a widow lady of St. Paul 45 years old - Mehitable & John they suppose are to be soon - Mr. Sargent is getting better slowly don't sit up much yet - we are all in good health now.  
Albina says she has felt healthier & stronger than usual this winter - I tell her that the care & culmination that falls up on her in your absence has it's advantages.

 tell her that the care & culmination that falls gives her fortitude perhaps, she is very chicken headed sometimes & mole hills seem like mountains.
The snow hides the fences all up the road - the nursery has been all out of sight for many weeks - How have you made out for clothes for yourself to provide yourself with things & decent & comfortable you ought to have carried more shirts & drawers ought not to get much mending done by Nettie.  Suppose she has enough to do.  Don't be so anxious to save money as to cheat yourself in any way of a generous living a man is estimated very much by the dress he wears you are very apt to not dress well enough.
I shall be lonely more this long spring, write to me often.  Ask Isaac & Nettie to likewise - Lucy wants very much & should be there next month which she weans the babe -  but tis bad going back & forth so often.
Completed

My Dear Children                                Cedar Grove Milo April 14th 1854

 We have just (7 oclock P.M.) reciev'd letters from you Dated March 31st & April 2nd. It is a little vexatious that we cannot say anything to you in less time than 2 or 3 weeks.  We i.e Albina & I have written every week since I came from Bangor.  I am afraid that the doleful letters we wrote about the time of the great storm - will trouble Charles & make him start for home Sooner than he would otherwise think it best to.  We have got Walter Rider here to stay all the Season if C. wants him so that we shall get along nicely. But I am some afraid that if C. stays there till June as he has talk'd of he will get the fever & Ague which would be dreadfull you know.
  He must do a great deal to his Barn before it will do to put hay in- but perhaps the Money he could earn must perhaps do it better than has time here. We want to see him bad enough and he will Suffer some losses by being gone but the probability is that for the rest of the time we shall get along almost as if he was here his fine Grey Colt has got the horse ail very bad & perhaps will die but that cant be help'd now

[upside down at top] I wish you and C. would find out every thing you can about S. Conant, his circumstances, state of mind etc. & let me know I suppose he is not communicative possibly Charles might get his confidence
Completed

The Snow is I suppose 2 or 4 feet deep in the woods I should think 2 or 3 feet on an average all about here

  I feel very sad about Dear Antoinettes health O how Glad I shall be when I hear that she is safe at home with her Mother I am afraid the journey will be too fatiguing for her I hope & trust that the Salubrious bracing air of her native hills will restore her to health & strength again - but I shall feel all the more impatient to see them when they are nearer. If you cannot leave your R.R. I dont care how fast you hurry it along if you will not expose health by it.
 Lucy poor naughty girl hurt herself at work which her girl was gone home to make a visit so that she is quite unwell ever since I suppose she is just about weaning her babe is just learning to walk too & he is a great heavy fellow & it takes too much of her strength  She writes that Eliab talks some of buying the Tebbetts House. He & Sam'l are likely to be fixtures in Bangor since they've gone so strong into the Mercantile business. I had a letter from sister Conant a few days ago She wants to know particularly about Sam'l. Anna writes that she is expecting Antoinette to stop with her 2 or 3 weeks or till they come in june says she is planning for me to home with her but I dont think it will be expedient  goodbye A.M.M.

[written across letter] I.S. Metcalf
Completed

Friday june 9th, 1854
My Dear Son  Albina just had a letter from you dated 21st of May  Charlie went down to the P.O. after it 2 days ago I had a letter from Anna they expect to be in Boston on the fourth of july - not to be here before the second week in july probably Isaac will tell you all about us here, you cannot think or imagine how surprised & glad I was to see him at Brownville & I feel troubled too that he has such luck & has to be so delay when he was so pressed for time I feel very grateful to him - We had a letter from Lucy Wednesday saying that she & Antoinette & Sam'l & the two babies & the woman to take care of them, were coming first of next week
We have sent to S. & I. for flour, Molasses, tea, Coffee, Sugar, spare fixings for the room, in fine for whatever they think we need. The water has been up twice over the intervale as Isaac will tell you  So that Walter is rather late about the farming - and yesterday we had another smart rain the ground where the corn has just been planted is some of it under water  it came up so as to stop them before they got it quit all plants today 
The trees & the grass have grown very rapidly considerable grass was winter killed but where it is not it looks finely the clover north of the house looks beautifully - the carrots, beets, turnips not sow'd yet - it has been so wet & Walter is not very rugged & there is many chores to do you know, when I get home from Brownsville I advised to hire some help and we have made out to get George Hodgham half a month for 5 dollars - there will be work on the road you know I have just ask'd him if he should like to stay here all summer if you want him, he said he would
Written on top of third line from the bottom
Sheep not washed or sheered yet
Completed

Walter wants you should come home before staying as--(tho he is a smart hand to mow they say if he is not his side is lame & he can't pitch hay or mow much I suppose-- I suppose you are earning more wages than the hire of a good smart man would be here (if one could be obtain'd)--perhaps it could be done or let out the hay but you know the Barn needs fixing and it will not secure the hay--& no one can do your work to just as good advantage as you can yourself--Mo' Walter seems interested & careful about everything as if it was his own & gets along nicely & if he can't do too much in a day it seems so he can better than the hir'd men we have usually had [seems more like one of our folks]

I feel afraid Isaac will work too hard do warn him & charge him to be careful of his health he looks very different from what he us'd to --- and do be careful of yourself and come away before you get the "shakes"

It is very very hard for Charlie to learn to read I get quite discourag'd sometimes & he does quit he has not tried much this 3 or 4 weeks past [we haven't tried to have him read at all] he had rather do any thing rather than look in a book--I went out in the back room last night & he was sitting alone on the floor by the stove looking very sad I told him he'd better go to bed-- he said he did not want to grow any bigger I asked him why? He answered because he did not learn he did not want to grow bigger he could learn but he is going to school next week perhaps he'll take a new start then

   I shall direct this to Isaac as perhaps it might not get there till you have started for home 
   If you do come home to do your Staying you'll get here before Anna comes

June 10th
Completed

To Charles                                                                    Thursday July 21st / 54

 I must scribble a letter tho' there seems to be, no need as Albina is writing a long letter there has been very fine weather for two weeks past we have had nobody at work but George alone till till yesterday & today lame. Mover has been here - they have been getting the thinnest of the grass - In the feild north of the house the grass is very thick & good & ought to have been cut this week so Waller says - expects to have 3 hands next week I hope it will not be bad weather when they get into the thick clover.  Waller feeds the pigs milks the cows does chores about house of which there is always a plenty you know a good many things that you or somebody might do if she was here - rides down to the P.O. to mill etc. etc. but says he will stay till after Haying if nothing happens - & then perhaps George can get along alone he is engag'd till harvesting is done at $12, pr month - you needn't expect all will go just as if you were here & that was none too well sometimes you know the colts are thin & poor especially the grey he coughs - will have the heaves or die in consumption before next winter is out perhaps I believe W.  thinks it not best to rowel him till the weather is cooler he has been rowel'd last spring and doctor'd doctor'd Mr. Kittredge spar'd no pains he had any amount of every thing put into his mouth & nose & ears etc. etc.  Mr. De Witt & wife and daughter came here yesterday have gone to Brownville today they expect to return to Bangor next Wednesday he is a fine Man have rather an expensive journey from a remark I heard Ann make I enfer that they spend about $500 in the journey
Completed

To Isaac  A letter from you and one from Charles to Albina this evening dated July 9th Antoinette with Sabra & the baby left Bangor for Dunbarton last Monday Ann says she didn't mean to keep Sabra only till she gets home and I am glad. I didn't exactly like her I dont know but she meant well but I didn't  quite like her treatment of the dear little Mayo Lucy and Mallie got quite disgusted with her in some other respects I hope & trust that Nettie will be well - enough to take care of him herself now he goes alone it will be so much better for him & eventually easier and better for her - by the way I differ from you- I would not have his clothes high in the neck  - the neck throat & bosom need the good fresh air I sure I thought that was your theory and practice. O how I did long to have him all to myself for a while. While there at Dunbarton I should advise to let him when the weather is fine run out door & play in the dirt bare neck'd  & bare foot only when teething the head should not be expos'd to a current of cold air - but how many words I have crowded  on to this peice of paper hardly thought of writing any when I begun.
Completed

Send the funny letter back & I'll send it to Nettie to comfort her.                          Saturday Agust 26th 1854
Dear Albin I must tell you the joyful news how that Maria had a little Daughter born this morning 7 1/2 oclock - was taken sick about one oclock in the night had a pretty hard comfortable time is quite easy & happy now baby nurs'd in an hour after it was born nicely weighed 7 lbs. Lucys health is rather miserable tir'd all the time. Percie we think is a little better yesterday & today - you would hardly know him he is so poor & pale his little legs look like little drumsticks weighs 18 1/2 lbs 6 less than he did 6 months ago. Lucy has already written a letter to Anna & to Nettie - we shall write to Charles & Isaac - and to Almeda.

  I feel troubled & destress'd at your destress about Charles but do my Daughter try to feel that it is all right & best - & trust in God that it will be so. He can enable you to feel reconcil'd and happy under any circumstances. But your trust & confidence in Him who is always near & never fails to attend to the wants of his children. There surely is great comfort under any - the most trying circumstances in thinking of & trusting in the goodness of God.
 Lucy talks a leetle that if Percie gets better before the weather gets too cold & if etc. that she & I had better go to Dunbarton this fall - but it is not very likely Hadn't you better come down here & make a visit I dont
Completed

why you cant perhaps your Father or Somebody may be coming so that you could save a part of the expense but if not you can come in the stage it isn't  much it will do you more good than the trouble & cost.

 My love to Waller & Sally & George and all the folks. Do write again soon.
 It is worth a great deal to have such a girl a Lucy has got not only capable & smart to work but what is more is so kind hearted cheerful & good natur'd - but we dont know how long it will last

Sabbath morning Sam'l Eliab & Lucy are gone to meeting. Mariah says she feels well enough to come downstairs She is really very smart & well. She thinks that she has receiv'd very great benefit from bathing not in cold water but just warm enough to be pleasant. She has taken sits baths almost every day till she was sick means to again I believe in a day or two

 I went to meeting all day last Sabbath heard Mr. Adams of New Jersey in the forenoon & Mr. Shepperd in the afternoon. Today have heard an excellent sermon by Dr. Clark of Hartford from Math 5 - 4 he made it out that all sorrow & greif is the fruit of sin. And the thought came to me - is not Albina's present distress & sorrow the fruit of selling her affections to much things of earth thinking more of Charles than of Him who Claims the whole heart - and will not permit his own dear Children to set anything else above him in their affections - but will send trials of some sort to warn them back to himself the fountain of all good of all
Completed

happiness. He can and will always remove our trials or make us to be reconcil'd to them if we only ask him aright - ask in faith - What is there in all the world like prayer - pray m Daughter pray for a Spirit of prayer. And your Greif that seems almost unbearable may prove to be one of the greatest of blessings by bringing you nearer to the great fountain of all blessedness. I intended to send this this morning but forgot it.

 Monday evening Maria has a Mrs. Baily for a nurse a nice kind hearted widow woman I should think 45 or 50 years old and if you want to see her look at your Mother her form and all her ways are just like your Mother We all like her very much.  Lucy would be glad to have you send her a bucket of Eggs  But Sam'l says it is not best because Mr. Gould dont love to be bother'd with 'em. But you could pack a lot so that they would keep - & perhaps Mr. Livermore will be coming. Sam'l brought home a bucket of Eggs last week & about half are rotten
                                                                                                             Tues. morning Aug. 29-
     Mother finished her writing here last night. She did not feel very well, went up stairs to bed, was taken with violent pain in her bowels, vomiting and purging, - had twelve very profuse discharges, almost like clear water (poured right away from her), in two hours after she was taken. She was very cold, had some cramp in her feet. Samuel went for the Dr. between 11 and 12 o'clock, Eliab flew up and down stairs waiting upon her and
Completed

doing everything better than a woman could. He got four or five hot flatirons, a jug of hot water and flannel ? etc. round her, and then it was some time before he could get her warm - meanwhile Percie was scatters, worrying & crying, so I could only attend to him, and "Energine" turning up in Maria's room, so the nurse had her hands full. Mother is releived of her Cholera morbus attack, and feels much better this morning. the only danger now is of fever - she is very weak & pale. While Percie sleeps, I keep the flies off & write - he keeps along about so - better one day & worse the next. These warm days & cool nights are very bad for the bowel complaints. For myself,  if all the rest were well, I should be sick, or at least give myself up to rest & recruit.  Mallie is just as smart as can be. I do not doubt she will be down stairs in less than a fortnight. Is just as happy as ever you saw any body - says she would go it all over again now, or would as soon as the baby was born, for the sake of having two.  Says it was nothing to what she expected! Can't you follow the example of the worthy woman who wrote the enclosed printed letter, & send equally encouraging epistles to Charles? Is'nt it a good "take off?" love to all - Aff. Lucy.
Completed

Written upside down on the top:
My health is good I was unwell a few days

Bangor Sept. 3rd /54
Dear Albina
I expected we should get a letter from you Wednesday  I do think a good deal about home & want to know all how you are getting along - How is Walters health now? Does George stay there all the time? - has Jane gone to Brownville & Sally come back? - Are you likely to have any harvesting to do? in some places the Corn Potatos' &c. are all entirely cut off & the pastures so wholly dried up that they have to feed cattle at their barns so they say  I hope it is not to bad on the intervale - If Charles stays till towards spring you will need to get a cookstove before he comes home & take care & get up plenty of wood early in the season.
Does Walter think any of taking the farm next year if C. wants to let it - Charles wrote to Eliab that he thought it might be best not to sell the wood but pack it away & keep it till another year unless the price comes up
Lucy says you had better come here soon - before cold weather & that Charlie had better come as soon as E. & wife move away which will be in a few weeks if she gets along as smart as she has done they have hired a house & are now paying rent for it will probably move by the first part of Oct. - when Charlie comes you had perhaps send what aprons & other clothes that he has - but if he is to have any new ones have'em made here Send the old cloak that was Janes & we can make it - his old boots would do to wear at home but not to well here perhaps you can fix'em up & save'em for Josie
Written upside down:
Much obliged for your letter rec'd last night 
Do write often love to all the folks good bye
Completed

we has a letter from Charles & Isaac a day or two since - will send C's & would Isaac's bit it would be double postage

 I think I will take off half the sheet and send it there is not much in the other half only he says Charles very deliberately & understandingly made up his mind that he was doing best to stay here - the advantages were greater than the disadvantages he concluded to stay and wisely sticks to it till he sees some cause to decide differently. He says he feels very bad when he thinks of home & the children but that he tells him to think of going to California or to Sea. And Charles acknowledges that even that is a great deal better than having no wife & children - says his own health is excellent even the drawth of this summer which is very extraordinary does not affect him - that he has to ride in the dust by day & by night but Charles works in the shade where he is not expos'd at all - he speaks of C's talking about coming home & going back I should not think that would be hardly worth while as it would be more likely to give him the ague - but let us believe that it will all be right and best and trust it there and not feel anxious about it

[left-hand side] if you can read this letter you'll do pretty well
[upside down within letter] Maria is very smart says she could go down and about her work as well as any body but means to keep her room a fortnight for fashion's sake the baby's "Energine" is its name is well & they are very happy

 Poor Josie I'm sorry he is sick tis ruinous to the constitution to take medicine especially Catonics I am afraid he eats green apples & things that are hurtful to him I would try to get along with care and diet and not give much medicine

no matter about the Eggs perhaps you had better tell them & put up some more for Lucy when the weather is colder
I feel how much you want to see Charles I pray for you and cry too -- but I feel afraid to have him come just as cold weather commences & if he come I suppose he will go right back again. Antoinette expects Isaac will get through by January or Feb. but I suppose nobody knows when
Completed

Friday Sept 22nd
Dear Albina  I feel so anxious about Mary and you that I can think of nothing else so I'm begin to write before you get home even - I seem as if I couldn't wait till tomorrow night before hearing from you I am afraid you will get sick carrying Mary so far in your arms
I got so tir'd and nervous yesterday that I even had a cry myself after I went to bed I had not been asleep when I went into your chamber - most two o clock  I got to thinking about Mary being sick & Charles gone &c &c &c &c
But I have been abed - had a good nap, & all looks bright & hopeful - tho' I feel anxious & shall till I hear   am sorry you didn't take the flannel or blanket to put round her feet
Sat evening 10 oclock have just got your bit of letter  I am so glad to hear that you got home well - I do feel as if Mary is going to be well right off  but must wait all the time Tuesday before we can know whether she is sick or not - I had lotted upon your having a good visit here but I hope you'll have a better one next time you come - Percie does seem to be getting better but it is very slow.  he is very nervous & fretful  very hungry but we fear to let him eat much
Up the left side then across the top:
27 I expected to send this tuesday but got disappointed had letters from Charles & Isaac yesterday Charles talks of coming home in Nov. or Dec. I am afraid he will be sick in conveyance but he has been so tried with our letters that I hope he wont have occation to alter his mind again
Completed

late Tuesday evening I have just got your letter & Charles's  am very glad to hear that Mary is better hope she'll be really well by the time you get this - You tell of giving her charcoal I should think it might be good a very little of it if you could get it fine enough but I don't see how you can with any means you have there it ought to be as fine as possible or it might do injury
The Dr was in today he thinks Percie is getting well  Ellen has got a very bad cold has not been able to do any thing since Sunday morning has been taking an emetic I guess she'll be better tomorrow - Eliab started for Boston yesterday we expect him back Saturday & Hattie Ely with him If we are all well they'll get mov'd next week I guess - Better send Charlie by the first of the week after perhaps
So Charles has determined on coming right home it seems - perhaps it may be all for the best - but I think it very probable that he will be regreting it all winter - If he gets through the winter without being sick I am sure I shall be glad to have him at home  but I think we have not much reason to think he will - but let us hope & trust that all will be well
love to Walter & Sally and all the folks
from your affectionate mother
I don't see why you wont all live there this winter if C does come home each family by yourselves thousands of families live more crowded than that would be i.e. if they want to
Completed

Bangor - Thursday Oct 12th/15th

My Dear Daughter
Mr Rider has just gone from here to Dr McRuens to have his face operated upon.   We can't but feel very much for him.  Almeda feels very bad tho' they both feel very glad he came.  Dr Mc Ruen a short time since perform'd a similar operation, only worse.  I guess he understand  it thoroughly he said it would take no more than 2 or 3 minutes to cut it out, & get it all done up.
Why didn't you send Charlie - I ask'd L what I should say to you about his coming Sam'l said tell her we've been expecting him every mail & all disappoint that he did not come & if you were writing he should come send him right along.  I expect his habits have been such in regard to doing pretty much as he have a mind to that he would require some carer and attention, but I think it would be a real benefit to him to be here a while - I don't think that his Father will be home till December.  We had a letter from Isaac yesterday dated Oct 10th in which he say, that he is expecting to get through there by the 1st of Dec. If so I thought it most likely they would come home together.

 If you send Charlie the sooner he comes the better you need not to fix him send him just as he is.  I can see about that after he gets here -----Send him right along Saturday if you can, if not Tuesday.  Percie is getting along nicely has gain'd most 2 pounds but him take comforter & mittens for it will be cold & he'll want to be out a good deal.  Please send my old shawl.
Completed

Dear Albina
I have just received your letter with Charles - Please inform me whether you got my two last letters one sent with Almeda, which she sent to Walker and one from me & Lucy sent by Mr.Rider, it was tied up with a bundle together with a bunch of 20 envelopes also 2 or 3 other bundles & put in your little red wooden pail & left probably at your Fathers - I conclude that by some unfortunate mistake you have not got them or you certainly have sent Charlies - but the time in part I suppose it is hardly worth while to have him come at all this winter now, certainly not unless he can come right off this week - it seems really unfortunate and much to be regretted that he has not been here these 5 or 6 weeks while they would
Completed

have been glad to have him and would have walked over him with so much care and attention to do him good & it certainly would have been a great benefit to him.  We have wondered and wondered why you did not send him - I have felt that instead of necessary great benefit - he has been all this fall very unfavorably situated - having his own head so much I am very much afraid that he is getting to be a great ignorant bad boy.  If he is not well instructed and gets any naughty habits it will be much harder learning the others to do right.  If by good fortune you should get this tomorrow and can send Charlie this week perhaps you had better send him - I really think it a great loss to him & to his parents that he has not been here this fall - I doubt whether they will want him in the winter.
Completed

I suppose Walter could not earn near so much on his farm besides paying his board as he will expect of Charles.  I should think he would prefer to stay.  I hope Charles will be home soon but I have all along thought that he would stay till they get done there which Isaac says will be in December he hopes by the first of the month.
I hope Walker has used the steers some & got them handy - Why did not they keep the oxen longer.  Did they not want them to plow & get wood.  Please write soon & say whether you get our letters.
I am staying with Eliabs wife while her sister is gone & Eliab is going to Boston tomorrow.  The baby grows nicely -  Percie is growing strong and fat he walks all about the house.
Your affectionate
Mother
Completed

Bangor Nov, 14th/15th

My Dear Daughter
I suppose you are busy now all day, making shirts & knitting stockings for Charles 3 or 4 weeks will soon pass away when we hope he will be at home.  I suppose he has written to you about the dreadful accident they have had there.  How shocking it must have been.  Nothing compar'd with many others R.R accidents but Isaacs coming so near being one of the victims and nothing so directly all about it affected me more than others that I have heard of where there were many more lives lost.  If you could send me some yarn I could knit some stockings for Charles as well as not - Lucy & I both spoke of it & intended to write to you that she borrow'd a little girls coat to make Percies by & behold it was made just like many a little blue one a pretty large yoke & plaited down with a belt round and a large cape.  Little children from a year old to Charles age all wear large capes to their cloak, whatever the form of the cloak may be - I hope you have not alter'd many, for it is exactly in fashion & it would be a good deal of work to fix it over.
Completed

Percie has just got one more eye tooth thro' has got two now the others swelld a good deal.  Lucy is very miserable a few days past with the back ache.  Went a shopping and got too much tired.  She is so apt to do too much before she is aware of it that I don't know as she will ever get well.  Charlie is a very good boy has nothing to make him any other way -  Charlie has been scribbling on a piece of paper what he calls a letter but he thought you could not read it so I write it off just as he told me - He has learn'd the way down to his Uncle Eliab's has gone down there now of an errand.

  Charlie came of his own accord the other day & wanted to write a letter to Mouver, so Mother helped him.  He was going to begin with Albina but Mother told him how this is exactly as he told it over. "Dear Mother, Uncle Samuel has got me some new boots. I tie up the cow every day & feed her and clean out the barn.  How do you get along nowadays without me?  How does Joseph get along & how does Mary do?  Does she have spells now?  (meaning sick spells)  Percie has got blocks a whole lot, some with pictures in them and play with them."  What a fine rain and what a dear day after it - with love, Sister Lucy.
Completed

Jan 15th 1855
My Dear Children
We have a letter from Isaac dated 7th Jan. He and his expect to be here in two or 3 weeks - is stopping to visit her friends
I have forgotten every time to ask you Albina whether you have seen my black fur tippet I suppose I wore it home last winter but I have tryed & try'd to recollect about it but I cant remember anything when I had it last or where I put it - I did not think of it when I left home I wonder why I did not
Charlie's little collars never left here thru my carelessness & I intended to tell you that Saml had your Chickens & sold 'em at the store and gave Charlie credit for them. What are you & Charles reading nowadays, or dont you have time to read anything
Lucy you know got very much rundown last summer I thought she would recruit again as Percie got better & the cold weather came & she has some but she is not near as strong as she was a year ago cannot bear near as much fatigue or exposure & Percie tho' he grows fat & large does not seem to be quite well - He has never been "just right in his bowels since he was sick
What a blessing it is to enjoy good health are you & I thankful enough. Maria has had a very bad cold and her baby too - We had a letter from Anna last Saturday She is well & happy as ever every time she writes she talks about having company - Some half dozen folks, to stay several weeks or just had a party or some such thing
Completed

I wish you write more and often I want to know how you are all getting along do write more about the Children you say little M frets & whines - one thing that I wanted to do is try to make her think she is a good pleasant child - I imagine that she has a strong impression (perhaps too strong ever to be removed) that she is a naughty girl - If she has it will have a great tendency to make her so - She is a very affectionate child & I believe she may become mild and pleasant
It is needful for children to be in the habit of fretting & scolding at each other - I would reprove it more severely than the doing of any mischief - I think it has a bad effect on their whole life - it is so much better to take things easy - to be always thankful & happy
O if I could only do as well as I can say what an example I should be for others to follow but - Alas!! I write chiefly for the sake of getting letters from you dont disappoint me it will do you good as well as me
Completed

Bangor Nov. 17 /55
My Dear Children,
If this reaches you in season i.e. before the Bundle is sent - I want you to send the pieces of my all wool Delaine dress I very carelessly forgot'em they are I think in the upper drawer of the new chest at the left hand end of the drawer - If not there look in the middle drawer - you may send also an old green velvet bag - which is also in the upper drawer - When I came away I did not think of my Cloak Sleeves at all - I usually have kept them pinned on to my Cloak - But they were not on the cloak when I got here - perhaps I have lost em no great matter if I did  If you see them there please lay them up - I do not want them sent
I am sorry I had to leave that chest & drawers so stir'd up & out of fix - but let them remain if I live to go home again I can fix'em then
I hope Mrs. S will send my little eye salve box as I shouldn't know just what to enquire for if I want to get more
Much love to you all from your Mother
I know I shall want the pieces of dress but I suppose is not worth while to send'em if you have already sent the other thing
Completed

My Dear Children
Here I am yet waiting for Isaac to get ready to go westward am as pleasantly & comfortably situated as any body need to be except that it seems as if it was not just where I ought to be
Isaac & Nettie are keeping house they have set the Father & Mother aside or rather they have set themselves aside & Isaac provides & Nettie directs all the household matters  She has very excellent help a tall dignified handsome well lived well inform'd kind hearted & pleasant agreeable in her manner, of a healthy & respectable family & with all good sense enough to know & observe the proprieties of her situation - how fortunate it is for Nettie that she can have such help while Isaac is gone
Completed

Isaac talks some of going round to Brattleborough on the way to call on Joseph Stevens & perhaps to Warwick - I was expecting to start next Monday but Isaac keeps pleasing - he is luying in provisions getting wood &c &c Says he has been married this some time & got quite a family of children & I have never made him a visit before &c. - would go I suppose if I insist upon it but it would be more convenient for him to stay a week or two longer on till it comes Sledding so that he can get his winters wood  I hardly see how it can be so but they [Mr. D] seem to have every convenience & luxury that one could expect if the Salary was 12 or 1500, instead of 400 - large cottage house well furnish'd tho' not in the newest while yet neat convenient & complete in every part (necessary paper'd & completed)
Completed

a great many people have call'd to pay their compliments to Nettie & the twins - It is very pleasant place here - much more so than I expected I should think it must be delightful in the summer 
These lines are Xd out:]
My Delaine dresses are both so worn already that I fear I shall need another for an after noon before I get to Elyria or have to put on my Alopine
The people about here as far as I can judge are rich live in great houses dress well &c but are probably like other farming places very industrious & economical
They have a prayer meeting every tuesday afternoon in the vestry a few steps from here - also one in the Pastors study the same evening prayers for their families & the church "family prayer meeting" a few good people have kept it up constantly for 30 years tho' sometimes no more than 2 or 3 attend Do write often - I have not written to Milo please send this if you are writing them
Completed

Dec. 13, 1855
Dear Sister Lucy
I this day send to you the December Number of Putnam's Magazine - The other numbers of the 6th Vol. are I believe with you; therefore I prefer to send this there also.
Please read this, and then if not too much trouble tie up the 6 Numbers of the 6th Vol. together, and lay them away to be found. It is possible that I may sometime visit Bangor again, and may get them. Do you hear from L.W.? 
Please write to us.
I expect Mother is homesick & she wont let me see what she has written.
I.S. & Nettie
Nettie says the twin infants are probably named
Willis Putnam & Wilder Stevens
Completed

Written across the top:
To Charles & Albina    1855
Dunbarton Dec 29th
My Dear Children
I thank you very much for your letters I was very glad indeed to hear from home I expected to have been gone from here long ago - but Isaac wanted very much to tary till we could have a few days of wedding -- & there has been no snow here till this week
The people here are very pleasant & genteel & very good - a good large cottage house very completely furnished -- the sitting room is 24 or 26 feet long & 16 wide with 4 windows warm'd by a stove like yours in the kitchen - it has a bed, large mirror & wash stand a good wide sofa (occupied chiefly by the two "tins" as Mayo calls 'em) a secretary & book case & a Seraphine on which Nettie plays sometimes
Written upside down:
I think I have got this sheet pretty full tho not well filled Much love Isaac
Completed

I wish you could see the dear little boys they have grown beautifully they hold up their little hands and look at 'em & laugh & crow they lay on the lounge by the hour at a time & hardly cry at all
Mr. P. has 9 1/2 acres of land which he lets out at the halves has no manure except from one horse he says the clear benefit last year was 90 dollars - He does no work at all himself.
Isaac & Nettie are regularly keeping house he provide & she directs the household
The idea that the blessing of God maketh such & that those wealthy individuals or communities get along the best who do their duty seems plainly exemplified here - there are about 900 inhabitants in this town their yearly contribution to benevolent objects is 200, a
Completed

year besides supporting a minister The people are merely farmers no kind of manufacturing done in town There is not even a grist mill the land tho' good perhaps is certainly very rocky & hard to cultivate & yet the people appear not only well off, but rich
They have a contribution regularly every 2 months in support of six different benevolent societies and doubtless are as a people the richer for it - they have a prayer meeting every tuesday  in the vestry a few steps from here - besides which a few Devoted Christians have kept up a meeting one evening in the week in the Pastors Study constantly for over 30 years their custom is always to have 3 prayers one for theirselves and families, one for the Church and people of the town & one for all mankind
Completed

Mr. S. says each acre of his land is as good as 150, at interest is'nt it strange that land is so productive here when it is so rocky & hard - But the people work as Gilman Rider does I suppose & they have a real good market for every thing at Manchester & produce is very high - higher than at Bangor
It seems as if the Boys, Charlie & Josie ought to be in school but I am very glad they do not go as it is - But I hope you will both take pains to learn them at home & it is better not to be done all in set lessons but incidentally every hour & almost every minute may admit of some question ask'd on precept enforced if your own minds are not too much taken up with work & every thing - you can do a good deal in that way - but I constantly would not try to have Charlie understand what he reads at present - I think that is the reason that he has been so slow to get the sounds & the combination of the letters I want they should learn to kind & polite to each other & to every body
Mrs. Putnam is a most perfect patron of ladylike politeness & kind attention to every body it is a great thing for a parent to have every word look & action such as ought to be imitated by child
Completed

Buffalo Jan. 9th 1856

My Dear Son, I suppose you would like to know something of our whereabouts well here we are & have been for the last 24 hours - we started from Dunbarton on the 2nd Mr. Putnam carried us to Concord in his cover'd Sleigh we took the cars for White River junction get along 5 or 6 miles to Fisherville when an axeltre broke & we had to wait while they sent back to Concord after another Engine & that made us behind time so that we had to stop from 4 oclock P.M. till the next noon at White River junction waiting for another train then we came on to Brattleboro' & stopt thro' Windsor, Bellow Falls & son on till next morning with J.A. Stevens then down to Northfield - took dinner at Mr. Parsons' (sister, Hannah & Maria there you know) then Isaac got a horse & cover'd nice sleigh & carried me out to sister Conants staid one night - Saw Sister Esther there we call'd 10 minutes at Mr. Russells and about 20 minutes at Brother William's (he too sick with a cold to go out) then back to
Completed

Northfield & spent the Sabbath then Monday morning call'd on Andelia a few minutes on our way to the cars at Vernon - & went to Albany by way of Springfeild at the Delevan house  At Albany Dam Isaac Monday night came near very near losing his life but by a smart merciful interposition of Providence we are yet alive. By reason of the evidence of the storm the Coal Gas settled down the chimney in his room flues stopped with snow.  Besides the doors which open'd into our rooms from the Hall which were both lock'd inside there happened to be a door one between his chamber & mine. I didn't get asleep till one oclock when my room seem'd so hot & close I opened the door into his & found him laid on the floor near the door without sense or motion I succeeded in getting him up opened the door & rung the bell for help got up the Hotel keeper etc. He soon got so as to speak but had no memory or conscious new of any thing - it was nearly two
Completed

hours before he could understand or comprehend his situation you can imagine better than I can tell what my distress was all this while when he got so as to talk he would half speak his words or begin to speak one thing & say another - would keep saying whats the matter Mother (& sometimes call me Anna what has happen'd to you - what is it &c. I thought of Paralesis, of every thing dreadful of his wife, & children, of my utter helplessness - I cant write it if ever I see you I'll tell you - He got better but had a dreadful head ache however he slept a little & got so that we started for Buffalo tuesday got here in the night - & here we are 2 o'clock thursday 10th the storm is so bad - Cars from Cleaveland just got here been 2 1/2 days from there  There are hundreds of passingers here at this Hotel & dont know how many at other places waiting - 4 or 5 car loads
Completed

(in which were 30 or 40 little children) besides hundreds of grown people
stranded off this morning and had to come back again Engines sent on from here to pull em back out of the snow - Several car loads out all night   Jan 12th  Elyria well here we are safe & sound in Anns really comfortable convenient & elegant house we started from Buffalo yesterday morning 7 oclock & arriv'd here at night having been there from Tuesday night till Friday morning  Anna & her family are all well except little Libbys eyes - I feel some fatigue & headache but on the whole pretty comfortable & very much at home considering.  Little Libby wants to be kissing me ever so much - Miss Woodbury is still here has been quite a help & comfort to Anna - has now begun a school and boards here
This letter is so mixt up I dont know as you can find out what it all means - But one thing you cannot fail to know i e how much cause we have for gratitude I am sure I never an hundredth part to thankful for sleep or quiet next and for my unrest on monday night - If I had slept on if I had not happen'd my dear Isaac would in all probability have been a dead corpse in the morning - It almost makes me shudder when I think of that night
Completed

Elyria Feb 21 1856
I have not seen much with my own eyes of this part of the Country it has been so cold & snowy - But I believe it is a very desirable place to live in. The Dr says if he was you he would sell out for what he could get - Thinks you could better yourself by taking a Farm here. Judge Hamilton who lives in this village has a house & garden & owns no other land. - Hires land of Judge Ely carries on considerable farming & supports a family & makes money - the Dr says he could get chances enough for you to take a Farm but that you had better sell your farm before you leave it he thinks that you could buy for 1200 dollars (hundred) in cash what would yield you more profit than your farm does - But the main thing is Society & literary and religious privileges - You can by great care & brains do considerable in the way of forming the minds of the children but after all they will be very much like the children they associate with - It makes me feel bad, how can they but be coarse rude uncultivated & boorish instead of the refin'd, amiable, well bred Christians
Completed

that we would wish them to be - It is true they may possibly become Christians where they are but are they most likely to - I dont know any thing about it but it seems to me as likely that Isaac will settle down somewhere this Spring as that he will go to Rail Roading I wish you & he could buy together somewhere here - i.e if it is best for you to think of ever leaving Milo - Whether it is best or not I cannot say but it certainly is time you had your mind fully made up on the Subject - To look at it one very important point of view it dont seem of much consequence where we are - we have but little time to stay it is not so much matter where we are if we only do our duty - I hope you will try this Spring to get settled in your own mind - in the first place think it over and see if you cannot feel Satisfied & fully contented to live & die where you are & leave it to your Children to hunt them up other homes if they should want to - If you can content yourself fully & entirely let that be it - & bend all your energies to making your condition & circumstances as comfortable &
Completed

desirable as you can - If you cannot & you mean to go away sometime at any rate - then I would advertise the farm & make every exertion to arrange your matters so as to bring it about in the shortest time you can - You have got to be too old to be years making up your mind on such a subject   I am glad all things considered that you do not send the boys to school & yet how much they need to be in a good school - Tho' Anna says in regard to Charleys reading - Dont worry about it if he dont learn to read yet awhile he'll learn something else - But I would be careful not to get him discouraged & thinking himself very dull for with his peculiar disposition it will prevent his trying to do anything - Commendation if you can only make him feel that he deserves it will do great things for him has Josie got so as to read some & does Mary know all her letters
Completed

I wish you could hear the Dr's prayers I never heard any minister more able, earnest, Spiritual Humble & various  I do think he is one of the best of men - just after reading in the Bible every morning each of us repeats a verse in the Bible  I have often thought of it & wish'd you would learn your children too   It might be a great blessing to them if you would constantly require them so you could early learn them while about your work  to repeat some sentence no matter how short at first - as love another - Children obey your Parents - ever so little of good learned & repeat would furnish great results in time
Tell the children I think of them very often & want they should be very good children and not forget the Grandmother that loves them all very much   God bless you all and keep you from every evil  A.M.M.
Completed

Dear folks at home                                                                     March 18th  / 56

  I have just receiv'd your good letters & thank you very much am very glad to hear anything you can tell me about yourselves, notwithstanding it makes me want to be with you
   And so you have got "Home,, how do you like it. I believe it is thought pretty favorably of we have seen 15 or so notices of the Book in different Newspapers which, most all of them speak well of it, some very well. Dont look upon it as a narrative of facts, as I fear you will be a little likely to do, for it is not. It is only a story with facts enough to build it on. But whatever you think of it say nothing about whose work it is not to your nearest friends i.e. to your father Kittredge family or anybody Anna would hardly forgive you if you do. (& of course you will not let any lady see my letters. I think we were unwise in reading your letters that you sent from Illinois to Waller & the neighbors so much as we did) I will send you one or two slips cut from Newspaper one from the Chicago Congregational Herald the other the Evening elect should like to have you save them as to any profit of the Book if there is any it will belong to the Publisher almost wholy.
Completed

I should think it a great deal better country about here for farming than it can be in Maine  Tis often the case or rather it is generally the case that here people are plowing & sowing in march but now the snow covers all the ground & has since Christmas it is warm & thawing to day & probably the snow will soon be gone -- The farmers say that cattle have wintered better look better & at less expense because of the steady weather tho' cold tis a great deal better than frequent rains & bare ground as is usual here. Such good sleighing is such a rarity in this region that folks have made great account of it in the way of sleigh rides in one instance some ways west of here  between 6 & 7 hundrfed people in one company & near by about an  hundred persons on horse back to escort them in to the town where they were going -- They had what they call'd a leap year Ball at the Beebe house close by here the company came from one of the adjoining towns - get up by Ladies they order'd all the arrangements about it paid all the cost &c. the young ladies invited the married men, the married ladies the young men - We have heard of a great many parties riding out from this town -- But we care for none of these things - Notwithstanding Anna has had
Completed

since I have been here 3 invited parties the last one the, Minister the Mayor, the judge, Member of Congress the Elite to the number of 35 or 40 the Tea sent round oyster soup - Biscuit & butter, cold meat (cut thin as a wafer) cheese pickles currant jelly & cake in variety & abundance a very pleasant time - good pleasant people - Anna & the Dr. seem to be lov'd & look'd up to by all the people round - and they treat me with mark'd respect I suppose for their sake - the custom here is to invite Families parents & children together one German Lady highly educated but could speak very little English her name Miss Eichradt - Hattie's Music teacher is a Miss Evarts an English Lady  She comes once a week stays one hour she has between 20 & 30 other scholars has 8 or 10 dollars for 24 lessons - Hattie practices on the Pianna about 3 hours a day I tole Anna that it would be better for her to be washing dishes learning to do house work - She says she knows it would but she had begun 3 years ago & Custom must rule - I just enquir'd of the Dr the price of land about here he says all the way from 10 to 50 dollars an acre according to the location & that frequently there are farms to be sold old men that have got rich & are giving up business - I suppose there
Completed

one chances almost every where to buy good farms every now and then if a body has money enough I have no doubt that the Dr. could & would buy or hire a good farm for you that would be advantageous & profitable if you want one & he could know just what you want or you could come here or about here somewhere & do it yourself. But the thing is you dont know that you want to & probably will not know till the time is past for doing it if you should want to you are hard on upon 50 you know - Besure it does seem that you have somehow mistaken your position that you naturally belong to a different grade from Mr. D. Mr L. & many of the folks about you - that you ought to have been somewhat different from what you are in mind & manners &c & the more I see of society the more I am convinced of it - But it is late in the day now & if you can be content to live along in the same way and if your children will be content to do the same it is all well - Provided that you can render up your account at last with joy & not with greif  But the higher our aims are the greater our efforts to be good and do good  the greater chance for happiness here & hereafter
Much love to the children and all of you from your Mother
Completed

Written sideways at the top:
I dont know when I shall return but I expect Anna will go with me unless Isaac or Eliab should have occation to come this way soon. A wont want to go till August or Sept but I guess she will  April 5th /56
My Dear son
you wanted to know about the price & rent of farms I will write you what little I can pick up about it - Dr. says small farms under cultivation can be bought for 1 or 2 thousand dollars or from 10 to 50 dollars an acre - unimprov'd for considerably less - more profit in raising sheep & cattle than grain sheep do well here & Ohio would bring a greater price than any other Tho' one man can take care of 20 acres of corn they just run a cultivator thro' it not hoe it at all  Many farms in this county give their attention wholly to making cheese keep a great lot of cows the men make the cheese and sell it off every Saturday night put up in boxes of 6 or 7 cents per lb all cash  cheeses weighing from 50 to 100 lb Timber - wood is of course growing very valuable but the Dr. buys his wood for 1,50 a load this year
He says if you were here with 1000, you could make yourself better off in 5 years than you ever could where you are now -- When the snow is all gone & the warm weather comes I expect to ride round the country some for the Dr keeps a very find horse & it is Anna's delight to be out in the air the Dr. dont go out when it is cold unless it is necessary he likes to have a warm room & stay in it - But Anna walks out every day almost cold or storm it makes not much difference says she can't feel lively & invigorated without the outdoor air - We have n't heard anything from Almeda since she went home nor anything from Bangor for more than a month - do write to me soon and often it will benefit you as well as me it is not decided yet but it is possible that Anna will go home with me when I go & stay a few weeks
Completed

Tell the boys there was gentleman visited here (whom had our large company) who was not as tall as Joseph he is neat & genteel in his appearance has a well formd head & shoulders about as large as other men, has taught school - been to California & all round the country is a person of good understanding & good education is now employ'd in the Lorain Bank in this place of which the Dr. is a President he is very agreeable & pleasant in conversation but he talks so funny with a little short hand & when he sits himself back in a chair his little feet stick right out strait - But no one who has any respect for themselves would suffer themselves to laugh at him
March 30  The weather here remains cold yet the snow is not quite gone whereas it is common for Farmers to get their sowing of grain done by this time - But I have n't known much about the cold weather for the house is warm'd by a Furnace you know a Register where the heat comes up in 6 different rooms so that all the rooms & the chambers are warm - I intended to write with a letter to Charles & Joseph this time but cant now I am very glad Joseph is going to be good as long as he lives & I dare say Charlie means to be as good as he I want they should let me know just how many lambs & calves and how many bushels of oats & of oats & peas - & more than that I want very much that they should be sure to learn something useful every day - & I do daily greive about you my dear Son & Albina, to think that you shut up there with almost no chance for your minds to grow & expand & if they dont they must be going down towards stupidity & ignorance - Your natural powers of mind far above mediocrity if only brought into use shut up as it were in darkness. O how I wish you could have the privilege of hearing such preaching as we have here
I send you a slip cut from an Elyria paper sleighriding is an uncommon thing about here usually
Completed

Elyria Lorain County
April 28th /56
I believe you owe me a letter Charles but I will not for it before writing again to you - because of Lucys being not well I expect to go home sooner than I should perhaps if all had been well. Anna is going with me and she can go to be gone in May & June better than later in the season because Miss Treadway a friend of hers who is teaching & boards here can take care of the children  She expects to be here only till the first week in July
We think now of starting about the 19th of May - Anna wants to visit at Dunbarton on our way will not be at Milo probably till the forepart of june  The Dr will go after her about the middle of June perhaps
The Dr. - Anna & I took a ride Saturday 15 or 20 miles to Carlyle, Laport & Ridgeville it is a beautiful country about here - It looks as if it must be much easier for Farmers to get a living here than in Maine
Completed

I suppose that less than one half the hard work that you have done on that farm would have made you independently rich here & probably 20 years ago you could have got a good farm here for half what that cost you
But the query is whether it is not too late now to pull up stakes if you should want to
It is a fine country for Fruit of almost every kind did you notice when you were here what fine thrifty looking apple & cherry trees higher than the top of this high house that have not growing more than 10 or 12 years  Pears Peaches quinces & grapes in abundance
The Dr. says you had better sell your Farm & come out here & take or hire some land for one season & that would give you time to look round for a place to buy - I would wish you could have been here years ago if it would do any good --
They are about Locating a ladies Seminary here in Elyria on the same without labor plan of Mount Holyoke they expect the cost to be about an hundred thousand dollars so manag'd that the cost to each pupil shall be no more than 60 dollars a year
Completed

I have such a realizing sense of the "March of Mind, & of the improvements that have been going on in Customs in Manners and in knowledge of infinitely various kinds and feel such a crushing weight of ignorance awkwardness & inability - that I have a great desire to warn you to make great exertions to keep up with the times
Possibly your children may remain boorish & ignorant all their days there is a large class of people that are so - & will be so - But you would rather they should rise & shine as lights in the world - Any one is culpable if they do not thrive to improve such advantages as they have & secure such benefits to themselves and their children as are attainable
You have the mind and the ability to do some good in the world besides just what you can do with your hands & probably there is somewhere a fit part for you to be in, in order to do it if you could only find it - However one ought not to think of that for you can and ought to do a great deal of good where you are or wherever you are - tho' I think your situation & circumstances have been such as would not call out the best powers of the mind to the greatest extent
Completed

I did intend to write a regular letter to the little boys - Tell them and Mary that I think of them a great deal and feel very anxious that they should all be very good children & learn to do right in everything because it is right - To be obedient to their parents and kind & pleasant & polite to every body - Tell Charlie he must set a good example for the others and try very hard not to be covetous I fear that he is too much inclined to be and now if they go to school to attend to them after they come home at night and inquire into their conduct their studies and their manners  Bad examples at school can be counteracted by right care and treatment at home above all things dont allow of any deceiving or concealing any thing children have great temptations to it - May God bless you all & keep you from every evil
Much love to all and each of you from
your Mother
Completed

Bangor  June 28th  /56
My Dear Son
I suppose you would like to hear how we are getting along I wish I had better news to write - I do feel almost discourag'd about Lucy sometimes: Some days she seems more comfortable but yesterday & almost every day she has pains & soreness in her side  many distressing back ache her food distresses her very much. Her stomach & throat so sore coughing all the time  her flesh very hot every afternoon
Cant lie down day or night  Sleeps bolster'd up or in her chair. - The stuff she coughs up looks bad sometimes blood & She raises I should think nearly or quits a pint every four & twenty hours  but not withstanding all this there are some reasons shy we are encourag'd to hope that all will yet be well
I wish you & Albina would write to me why dont you - I do so want to see the children & know just how you are all getting along
Completed

I wish James would write to me I would write to him but my time is very much taken up  there is enough for me to do to get ready every day
James has written some very good letters to Lissie I hope they'll do her good  they surely ought to -- She is a little carried away with false notions her perhaps & is to much of a magpie  does not realize but what all the world is made for her -- She just needs that true Humility which divine grade bestows  She seems not quite so pleasant & lovely in her disposition as when she was here before -- But it is a critical time of life with her a year or 2 will probably make a great change in her & doubtless for the better -- I think she is improving now there has been some perceptible change for the better since I came -- I think Caddies influence not the best tell James to write to her often
Completed

If you can conveniently I wish you would send me some money a V will enough for the present & do write often and much
to our Mother
Much love to Albina & the children  How I do want to see you all good bye
Completed

Bangor Sept. 11th /56
My Dear Children
The dear precious little babe is gone it died yesterday morning about 7 o clock -- This morning it is buried -- The coffin opened & it laid in its mothers arms  we had no funeral except Prof. Shepherd pray'd with us & the sexton came & alone the little baby was carried away -- But I Charles the hand of God is heavy upon Dear Isaac & Nettie -- Dear lovely little Mayo how we did all love him  But they I fear they worshipd the gift rather than the giver -- and it is taken from them  It is indeed a heavy blow  God grant it may be I am afraid to them that they may be submissive may see the perishing nature of all earthly things and
Completed

and set their strength more on heaven O how one & another is calld away how soon now very soon we'll all be fix'd in an eternal state  O may all these things help us to see & feel that Christ is all of happiness & enables us to throw ourselves entirely upon his mercy to live to Him -- What is all the universe good for if we have not an interest in him and serving Him we posess all things
Sam'l has propos'd to Eliab to move up here & keep house -- They have not yet concluded to -- I dont know whether they will - I wish they would I think it would be better for 'em & certainly much pleasanter for me  cant write now very well
Much love to the children
good bye
Mr C. W Rich
Completed

Bangor  Jan 1st 1857
My Dear Children
I wish you all a very happy new year -- & I thank you very much for a good letter I receivd from you a day or two since
I am very glad the boys go to school & are learning hope they will not suffer themselves to get their heads full of play while school keeps because they can play after school closes when it will not be so good a time to learn  am very glad too that Mary is learning to read
Tell them I want very much indeed that they should always be kind & pleasant to each other & never speak cross but always in a polite and pleasant voice & if they will all mind the golden rule they wont have occation to speak cross
About Marys dress & cloak I have noticed only one little girl who lives near here but she is I suppose dress'd in the "pink of the mode"  She goes to singing school & dancing school! is not quite six years old!! she has a thibet cloak belted
Completed

down -- with a cape they wear capes not near as large as they did last winter so Hattie & Maria say -- The winter is so far gone that I dont know but I should let her wear that blue one if you could get some ribbon just the color and plait on round the cape it would make it I guess about as large as they wear them now -- & they've got the fashion worse than ever about wearing little girls clothes short -- The dresses just about to the knees & the little while embroiderd drawers just come below the garters -- It seems ridiculous to me but fashion will be fashion
Samuel talks of being gone 3 or so weeks this winter visiting in N.H.  & looking about in Boston & elsewhere  Dont calculate to go to Minnesota till summer I guess  Percie has had a very bad cold had the croup twice tho' not very bad  cold bandage on his neck retriev'd him
Eliab & Maria talk of going to Milo  Maria wants to go very much -- Tis possible they may go some
Completed

time next week if the weather is mild & pleasant tho' I have nt heard them say when nor heard Eliab say that they certainly should go at all -- if they go I think it will be before very long for I dont think M will keep about till March
was n't you pleasd with the likeness of Lucy that Sam'l gave Charles -- He got six of them was n't he good to give us all one -- He is good I love him like an own son  I have always lik'd him but he seems nearer to me since Lucy's death
I wish you would write often I feel interested in every that is going on there
Did n't Charles go home pretty well loaded
I feel almost as well as before I was sick only not so strong  I have some cough yet and pain in my right side occasion'd the Dr says by adhesion of the Lung. but I think tis getting better
Eliab is very busy collecting money is not very well complaining of pain in his side and shoulder  much love to you all
from your 
Mother
Completed

Bangor Jan. 20th /57
Dear Children,
Sam'l says you could not find my keys to open the Bureau Drawer I presume you'll find them in my old work basket in the closet in my room that is where I generally keep them  I don't believe Isaac cares much about those old books that S. brought down - But probably there are some papers in the drawer that he wants, & memorandum Book &c
Did S. say anything about matching yarn he told me some time ago that he would rather you would let him have stocking yarn than pay him money for those things as it was not so easy to get it at Minnesota but it was before he knew that Almeda had sent any  I have footed 3 pr & there is enough to knit 3 pairs & I suppose that will do but if you have any that you don't want to use this winter I guess you had better send it - that Almeda sent is very poor uneven & so slack twisted  As to the Secretary I should be glad on Sam'ls account to have you take it but it is a great heavy thing and
Completed

not as handsome as your Old Desk would be if it was mended & new trim'd - However if you know that you shall not move away perhaps you had better take it  But Samuel says you will go west - that you can be better off if you can disperse of your property there for half what it is worth to go, to say nothing about the benefit to the children  A letter came to S. from his father while he was gone & another since he came back  He writes that John has lately made quite a purchase of a share [10th] I believe of a new town just laid out - & with a valuable Mill privelege  I dont know as I remember right but I believe he said he could sell it now & make $10,000.   Sam'l talks that he shall take Percie with him when he goes in the Spring  It makes me feel sad I and I suppose it would be hard for him to leave him & be so far from him - But it seems as if it would be better for P. to stay here a year or two  I know they cannot any of them love him or bear with him as we do( I don't know how he is going to get him there for he dirties his pants every day or two)
You have family enough, so that you would'nt want him there but it would be better for him to be there with me than to go among strangers
Completed

His Father cannot be with even if his business should be such that he could have him board at the same place he can't know but very little how he is treated  The Child needs dicipline as well as tender affectionate care & love  Lucy was so anxious that he should be with me - Said there was no other way that she could think of that she could take any comfort in thinking of - I suppose Almeda wont be glad to have him with her - But I expect Sam'l will think he must have him with him (& wants to show him to his folks)  Sam'l starts today for Boston N.H. &c - He thinks that James will go west & that Almeda will & Eliab says he shall go west. That he shall stay in Bangor but a few year longer 
S. says I had better go out to Elyria when he goes that all my Children will be out that way in a few years - I do not know what I may conclude but I dont feel now as if I should go next Spring I have not been with Almeda much this long time I don't feel like leaving her now she is in trouble
If I do not go west & shall if I live expect to be at Milo Mary Ely is coming here before long & I guess Sam'l Ely will be here next summer too but I dont know with much love to you all from your Mother

you better make haste if you are coming down or the snow will get so deep that it will be worse travelling 

 E. & Mallie will not go to Milo this winter Do write more particularly all the news all what you are doing  How the boys get along at school etc. etc. etc.
