Bangor Feb 21st /57
My Dear son
I write a few words just to ask what you say and think about having Percie at your house and Almeda's this coming summer - I thinnk S. is more than half inclin'd to let me keep him - I know that Albina has care enough & I dont know but she would feel it a burden anyway but if he should be there I would be there too to take care of him. Eliab would be very glad to have us both stay here, & on some accounts it would be pleasanter but on the whole I should prefer not to - The children at Elyria are urging me to go there with Percie & Sam'l would prefer that to any other way - But he is expecting to go in about 4 weeks from now - & considering Almeda's trials & that I have seen her so very little this long time - it seems as if I cant go away so far so soon again But I want to know what you & Albina & Almeda think
Completed

Now do please write to me & tell me what I had better do & write immediately - Are not you coming down here soon I wish you would i.e. if it is best & convenient for you - could nt you get James to hay there while you come down here - we are all in good health now Irving has been quite sick with Lung fever about a week but has got about well now- Mary Ely came here about a week ago will be here all summer - I suppose Sam'l Ely will come in the spring - This will be the Home for them all I guess
I'm sorry I did n't think to write a day or two sooner as I fear you wont get it for almost a week
love to all the folks  good bye A.M. Metcalf
24th  Eliab has got his cow & she is a noble looking animal gives 2 quarts more milk the man says than the calf can take calf 10 days old - a nice looking one & a "heifer calf' too I wish you could have it E. is going to sell it he can have 2 or 3 dollars for it - the cow is large gives very good milk - 50,00 so not very high for it I guess I intended this should have gone Monday do write soon - very soon
Completed

Bangor August 19th
My Dear Daughter
I dont think of any thing very special to wish to write but yet feel inclin'd to scribble a little - chiefly because I want to hear from home perhaps -Lucy had letter from Isaac yesterday came in seven days from Mt Hawkins he & Charles were then in good health but we see by the papers that the cholera is round about in all the western Cities - The season is to far advanced now that I dont feel so much fear of the boys having it as I did - Isaac didn't say a word about Charles's coming home - I want very much to hear what he says about coming home after getting our letters  It seems that they are suffering very much there with the draugth the grass all dried up & the corn all spoil'd for eight weeks, Isaac said they had had no rain at all
I want to hear whether it is as dry at Milo as here the trees are dying & the corn in the garden all drying up the grass looks as brown as in november - What do you do about corn for the pigs - I believe Eliab said the price of corn is 85 cents he says if you want any supplies send to them/ Furber & Metcalf) of course - They can use to advantage & want to, all they money they have and
Completed

a great deal more & suppose but expect to furnish what you need - Have you sold the wool? Is Charlie at the Village yet? - I wish he could be at Almeda's while James is with you
Maria is about quite smart yet - Percie is better but not at all well - his gums very much swollen & his bowels in a bad state - don't play about on the floor any - but is very patient & quiet - Sam'l & Eliab are full very full of business - I should be glad to have you get some yarn spin enough for one pr womens stockings about middling fine & send it when you do the next & if you can get some yarn ready for Charles some stockings, I can knit it for you If he needs them I dont know whether he does - I guess I had got enough knit for Charlile & I suppos'd those that he had an were to small would be enough for Josie 
Am much obliged to you for sending Charles letter will send it back I shall feel really worried about Sam'l Conant till I hear from him & his family I think he would be more likely to have the cholera because he is so nervous and afraid of it
We had a letter from Anna today she arriv'd home the Friday after leaving here all well - if you can get corn there just as cheap there it is just as well I suppose
Your affectionate A. M. M.

Dunbarton Dec.

My Dear Children  here I am just waiting for Jane to get ready to go It is a much more fine & pleasant place here than I expected to see I think it must be delightful in the Summer season. Mr. P. is very ? & ? very agreeable in conversation - has a vein of humour about him is rather precise never does any work except to take his horse will have a good horse has a 4 wheel'd Chaise or Carraige a Common wagon or Gig & nice cover'd Sleigh

Mr. P. is very lady like well bred as kind & attentive a possible doing every thing for every body in the most polite manner
  A very Convenient house very comfortable & completely furnished  Isaac & Nettie keep house i.e. he provides and she directs the household. I thought best that Nettie should take the Charge & Mrs. P. was willing as she needed rest however she does & will keep doing taking care of the babies or something. Mr. P. leads in family worship in the morning & Isaac at night. I have wonder'd why Isaac was unwilling to in the family at Milo as he did in his Chamber after they retir'd to bed

Feb. 18th

   I had written the above a long time ago when at Dunbarton & put it in my port folio to finish another time & forgot all about it - perhaps I have written the same in some of my letters that I have sent but no matter It will do no harm to write a little more on the same sheet

I wrote to you but a few days ago but I was going to tell you a little more about Isaac tho' I dont know much for he couldn't tell himself There seems to a quarrell with the Government about the R.R, or a waiting for a decision of the Supreme Court or something that stops their commencing work . I guess Isaac hardly knows what to do. He went to Maddison Wisconsin I suppose to see whether he didn't want to buy there he show'd me a Map of the place & pointed out some Lots which as he said he did not buy I suppose from the way he told it that he did almost conclude to buy there - it is the capital of the State you know & is or is to me the terminus of a ? or so of R. Roads - is but a few years old & has $000 inhabitants very healthy place etc. etc. etc. about the Latitude of Ohio.  I am afraid I gave you wrong impressions about the Dr. by what I wrote about him in my last letter he is a person of very strong feelings & it is difficult for him to control himself when anything affects him very suddenly but he is a good man not only a perfect Gentleman that will not do anything unkind or anoying to anyone but he is one of the most perfect Christians that I know- not only very & truly polite but very right in every thing- he is in the Bank at 10 oclock & gets home at 4 in the afternoon he read loud to us more or less everyday - as for me I suspect I am in danger of passing for something more than I am for People have seem to think that Mrs. DeWitts mother must be somebody pretty smart and they have not had time to find out their mistake
Completed

My Dear Children 
                                                     I feel as if I should very much enjoy being with you now you have none but own folks. Given I shall go home in 4 or 5 weeks - perhaps sooner  
       If you find you must get a Stove & a good many other things would not you do well to come down & get them & not stop much. But come down and make your visit after I get home.
  It seems as if you wouldn't leave home both together so well before, as after I get home as I could help take care  Eliab is now gone to Boston. Sam'l talks of going to Pennsylvania. Whether you think of ever leaving Milo or not now is a good starting point a good time to begin any new regulations  

O that you would be wise that you would be willing to do what you know & feel to be duty.

   How nice it would be Albina if you & Charles could get your supper & chores all out of the way before dark & then set out your table & lights * Books & make a settled point of instructing the children they are old enough to learn a great many things - besides beginning to read there is a great many way in which such children 

[left-hand side and top]  Charlie you know will be round with you and there's scarcely an hour in the day but you may be learning him something pulling out words - learning him names of newer terms etc. to count to add numbers etc. etc. work he will learn easy enough you'll need to keep his mind from work - but first and foremost an exact obedience - he is very prone to disobedience in little things is not willful about it but needs vigilant watchfulness with a great portion of patience and Mildness Alas how much easier to tell than to do Who is sufficient for these things but be not weary in well doing How reasonably & proper to daily seek the help and blessing of God in such an arduous but delightful work 
Tell Charlie to be a good boy & remember all Aunt Lucy has learn't him  I will try to write to him one of these days much love to each & all of you Do write to your Mother
Completed

might be interested & learn what they need to know if it was only by asking & answering questions just a short time every evening & then read some in the Bible.
I think no parent can feel justified or expect the blessing of God if they do not read the Bible to their children & make them sit still & listen - but not too long at once
All lessons for little children should be short & made interesting if possible. I should like to be at home to enquire out and hear all the incidents & everything that was said & done out to Ducoign - & hear the multiplicity of plans and cultivations for the future - And make some arrangement about property matters but I can't be in two places at once - I am very conveniently & comfortably situated here in regard to going to meeting & every thing - I cant do any body much good any where so it is not much matter where I am in that respect - unless it is to be where I should make the least trouble
If you both would only write often long particular letters  I want exceedingly to know all your doings & sayings (your thoughts) all your cogitations & plans for the future
The Hymn "Whene'er I take my walk abroad" beginning on the 222nd page of "Songs for the little ones - Charlie began to learn I want he should learn it all, the more he learns the easier he can learn, somebody must take pains with him in order to his learning I should think that Lucy repeated to him the 2 first verses of that hymn more than 50 times - But we
Completed

know that he can learn many other things he does learn easy enough so that he can get book knowledge - "If the tool is dull put to the more strength"
If you will recollect a conversation I had with you about 7 years ago on neglecting to cultivate the intellect and allowing the whole soul & mind to be absorb'd in the things of time & sense the mere animal you may see a reason why Charles has no love for a Book & let it induce you both to put forth great & unwearied effort to counteract the tendency to, all animal & no Soul remembering that whatever good you accomplish with the eldest is more than half accomplish'd with the younger ones for the copy will be follow'd whether good or bad
I punish'd Charlie once while here with a rod for improper immodest behavior - I wish he could be induc'd to tell exactly about it - but tis better for him that he should not know that I mentioned it - He has fine & tender feelings - has the stuff in him as Lucy says to make a noble & excellent man if rightly train'd
It seems to me that if I were you I would make the training the minds of the Children the all important work whatever else is neglected that should not be their - manners too should be daily & hourly attended to
I have a keener sense of it from seeing so much that appears uncouth & really impudent in Charlie without his being conscious that it was in any way improper - I am aware that there are many obstacles to overcome but they can & must be surmounted

Dear Brother and Sister

    Mother desired me to occupy this page, which I am glad to so. If we, her perverse and degenerate offspring, did only "practise all the precepts" she from time "inculcates," what patterns of excellence should we not become? I second her wishes & advice with all earnestness in regard to Charlie. As Mrs. Lee says, "the battle is half over if the first one is brought up right," and it does seem to me of great importance that little things be attended to in his case. "Life is made up of little things"you know. It does not become such as I to give advice, I know, but your Charlie is a fine natured boy, sensitive, susceptible to impression, capable of making a noble man, a fine specimen of humanity, but it seems to me that he needs very peculiar treatment - very gentle and very firm; more of the latter perhaps, than would be necessary if he had not been a good deal left to himself of late. His will must be bent, but if his spirit is broken, or greatly mortified, it would be his ruin. It seems to me that he must either make a very good character as he grows up, or a very wild, wayward one. It seems to me that the great thing is to keep his confidence, as our Mother did ours. I do feel particularly anxious Albina that the comparatively little ( nevertheless important in their plan) matters of bons, thank you, if you please,  yes sir and no sir, etc. etc. he not neglected - "here a little & there a little", will accomplish the matter & if they don't get such things when children there is danger that they will always be boors. All which is respectfully and lovingly submitted  - no more for lack of room - sis Lucy.
Completed

  we look that she may drop away any time or possibly may live some days
 May God enable us to say & feel 'Thy will be done'

we will write again if any Change

Lucy ask & the Dr. this morning how long he thought she should live he said he could not tell I think tis probable she may live a week or more but it would not be strange if she should not a day

Wednesday morning 13
  The Dr. looked very joyful when he came this morning told Lucy he has quite a good opinion of her really thought She was creeping up a little Most everyone has thought she couldnt live The nurse if she ever gets well it will seem the most like a miracle of any thing she has seen that she shall never despair of any body again She is very low - Coughs very dreadfully yet - but her breathing is somewhat reliev'd - & pain not so severe 14th we really cannot tell whether she is getting better or not. we should take great encouragement that she is no worse if it were not for her cough The baby is living but very feeble It weigh'd 3 1/4 I cant percieve as yet that it grows strong any we have a good nurse who takes all the care of Lucy She is strong & can lift her and I take the whole care of the babe I feed it by rolling up

a little rag & put one end in its mouth & lay the other in a teaspoon of milk & water & she sucks it out give her one teaspoonful once an hour it appears to be well only so feeble cold & lifeless that is a great care night & day to watch it & keep it warm

  Lucy is so patient & uncomplaining. I have never heard one murmuring word thro' all her dreadful suffering.
 Eliabs family are gone down river for their health Mallie & baby were unwell. Mallie writes in a letter to me that they should much rather be at Milo with you - & asks me if it would be too hard for Albina if they should take Ellen the Irish girl with them says she dare not take the baby home till the sickly season is over - she wrote to Eliab to know what he thought of the plan says that Hattie likes Albina & wants to go that they shouldn't be lonely there etc.  write to me monday what you think about it

Pray for us that we may be able to say & feel "Thy will be done,,

My Dear Son I understand you to say - you made no pretentions to Religion. Have you considered the full meaning - the awful import of that saying. There is no neutral ground. Are you willing to consider yourself in the enemies ground fighting against and throwing your influence against the cause that your Mother, your wife & all your Brothers & Sisters love so well. Spurning the love of Him who gave his son to die. Him who suffer'd & died to give Salvation to all freely who will accept of it. O my Son you cannot in your heart feel willing to seperate yourself from God - from all holy beings & be sinking deeper & deeper further & further as in that case you must from all that is good and holy

  There is no neutral ground for you to stand upon & your example must take its full effect on your Children. Can you wish them not to belong to Christ --you must be however slow your progress approaching nearer to God and Holiness or receding from all Good, all happiness

Nettie's health is a good deal better than when she went from here.

A week ago last Saturday (18th) we had a great snow storm so that it stopt the stage etc. blow'd & drifted a good deal And last Friday 21st began about the greatest snow storm that ever I knew, snow'd very fast all day with a strong east wind. Saturday it snow'd some & blow'd very hard all day from the west & continued to blow till Monday night. Before the last snow the fences up the road were all cover'd up and the road fill'd up as high as the fence now I presume the snow is more than 10 feet deep on many places about the house. I wish you could see how deep the snow is. It was said to be full 5 feet in the woods before these two last snows. I wish I could give you some general idea of matters & things here. The Sheep I guess will turn out same as they did that winter that Hiram took some of them. I suppose Uncle Mark was very careful - but perhaps fail'd in judgment I believe he thought best not to give grain to the Sheep in the first part of the winter. I was gone most of the time while he was here which was only 7 or 8 weeks. I think James has very good judgment for a boy about taking care of sheep etc. But of course was more intent upon his school, & having a good time than anything else I think he meant to be faithful. But it was very cold the fodder not very good, no convenience for giving grain to so many Sheep & he you know has to leave 'em from 8 oclock to dark in order to fix & get to school when he work'd to. Sinces James went home we've had a man one week the rest of the time we have depended on little Sumner (tho' Stephen has been here some) Albina has had a hard time taking care & she you know cannot  bear it as Mrs. Caton & some others would, she cant bear up under any little discouragements Stephen dont know anything about taking care at the barn, nor Sumner much Tis said there never was a time when it was so almost impossible to hire help

[upside down throughout letter] you will do well if you can find all I have written hope you are not very much hurried expected to have sent this several days ago, but as we did not have kept filling in more and more - your directions about the farming work will be very useful & necessary I guess we shall get along nicely now but I will have spells of saying Charles must come home. Anna expects to come here in June I think Nettie had better be at Elyria a while before going to N.H. the change will not be so great
I have just climb'd up & look'd into the Corn Bin, 1/2 or 2/3  of it remains there, pity it couldn't have been given to the Sheep. - or sold it has been worth 9/ a bushel is about 7/ now 9 or 10 lambs in the last 2 days have died A. has been to the barn every day while Sumner has been here she'll have an easier time now I hope.
Completed

It requires some of Mr. C.W. Rich's Judgment to get along with all our disadvantages & difficulties - we have too many sheep, or the farm is too big.

 It is very favorable for us that this dreadful Storm did not come in the terrible cold weather. I have felt very anxious ever since I cam home that there should be some way to seperate the sheep by making another yard & shed so that they could be fed with corn but we couldn't accomplish it "no how,,
 There seems so many difficulties in prospect like poor fences, lack of good farming tools - lack of judgment, discretion, & other qualities in a kind man if we can get one that you had better consider well whether it will be best for you on the whole to stay so late as you were intending. But you of course know pretty much how things are here. And how you are situated there. If you should stay there a little too long and get the "Shakes,, you might have? it all your life long.
  You are apt you know, when you begin any piece of work to feel such a strong inclination to finish, that you are not willing to leave it, when you know there are other things more necessary to be done - you must guard against that in making up your conclusions about coming home

Tis Monday afternoon - there has no person pass'd here since last Thursday, & by the appearance of the road I should think they couldn't for a week to come - probably we shall all feel better when this wind ceases and the warm weather come.
Mr. Medar has not got back- we dont know whether he will - if he does or we get any body else, we will write again. A. sometimes gets overburdened with care - tis hard for her  if she could only throw it off, as it seems as if I could, - but she cant, she will no?ng? greatly by spells. I have to be all the time telling her how much better off she is than any body else about here.
[left-hand side] March 29th we had a letter from Anna, she says you have not written to her any hardly

Your write so seldom that I know but little how you are getting along - we are both in the nature of things near the end of life's journey. Completed

Isaac is busy all the time with public business has hardly time to attend to his own necessary affairs being Town Trustee. He has the Poor of the town to look after

James strange or it may seem is at the head of business under the counsel & direction of his Mother Mills works for them at 15,00 a Month he seems just as interested & apparently more contented & happy than he us'd to be - & tis not strange by selling he has reliev'd himself of responsibility - only himself to look out for - ready to emprove any opportunity to better his situation Tis well for James that Mills can be here, he is a fine young man - probably he never will know how great a benefit Almeda has been to him

Warwick. December the 17.

Dear Cousin

  I once more take the pen of corrospendends to converse with you uppon religion
 O my friend how little do I live up to what I profess and how little progress do I make in liveing an holy life, how dul and stupid do I live in regard to my Dear Redener how has done so much for so an unprophitable a creature as I am. I often think that I am an stumbling block to others, and shall strenghten the hands of wel doers. Is it  possible that heaven can be my home while it has so few of my thoughts. How can I love my Savour God, with his superlative love and counttence so feebly affects my heart. If Jesus is mine and I am his why am I not constantly enraptured with his beauty and glowing with zeal for his cause. And I now desire to implore pardoning mercy of him how has said, him that cometh unto me shall in no wise be cast out. I think I do try to deny my self and to mortify my sins and lusts, thou I ought to be more strict and resolut, & think I love God and am dispose to acknowlede him just and righteous in all his ways and mercyfull to all his followers. But I am to often discontented with my lot hear and to ready to repine at the hand of proveadence  But when I realise what Bleassings we enjoy more than some part of the human race I think we never ought to complain at any thing that takes place ever so controrary to inclinations but we ought to be recconciled to our lot to hear and to thank our Heavenly Farther that our loins have ? to us in pleases so pesent  Whot reasn have I to rejoice that I am yet shared to plede for mercy, while thousands are called to bide a duie to all things hear below in an unexpected hour that they may think not of. And we now not whose turne it will be nese for we have not a moment that we can call our one

How nessarary is then that that we should be up and doing while the day lurst for the night of Death cometh when no man can work. And I ernestly wish for that Wisdom that skill enable us to eviece to the world that we are followers of Christ. That we have fixed our hopes and affections on a brighter world than this, and I pray that our lamps may so shine that may induse others seek our Blessed Redemer while he is to be found. O my friend we are sure to approch the Lords table if we are premited those to commemorat the Dieng Sufferings of our Savour o that we nay com in that humble and penitent disposition of ? that we ought to is the sincere wish of your friend

Dear Sister                                                                                                        Warwick Dec 25 1847

  I have not writen to you since last winter and I dont know as I shall make out now but I will try. last winter my health was very good but in April I was taken with the influenza had a dreadful cough and sore mouth lost my appetite and suffered a great deal for 4 or 5 weeks but after I got up I was pretty well through the summer about four weeks ago my well arm was taken lame it pained me nights but after I got rest I could work all day till last week it was taken worse I was afraid I should I should entirely lose the use of it but it seems to be gaining now but it is very lame yet. if it has been the other arm I should had a Dct. Seen it but that bunch dont trouble us any more than it did two years ago I suppose it grows Some Mr. C is pretty well for a man 72 but he is Deaf and you know he never was like Aaron Bass in the house but Hannah does every thing she can for me So I am well. I suppose you no Esther has gone to Barnam  She said she had been confined there ? years and I suppose had to bear a good deal. She got a little nervous and fretful said she needed some change so she came here and stayed awhile got all ready and Harvey carried her to Brattleboro the last day of Nov then she went in the Stage but had to stay all day and all night in Woodstock So it cost her something but I have had a letter She enjoyed the journey grandly she says I think they are glad to have her there but there is no chance for her to lay up any thing She works very dilligently has a great desire to do good in the world and really has done a great deal of good in this town if she was here and well she would do me good now. I suppose you no Samuel buried his youngest child last winter they both felt the loss greatly it was certainly a lovely child 16 months old. Brother Josephs folks are all healthy and happy as usual Humphrey came home before thanksgiving they had all the children and grandchildren and Isaac came out that morning came up here but promised to go there to supper So we could not keep him. Brother Says he likes his business and they like him very much. I dont no but you have various kinds of trouble but I do think you have great reason to be thankful that you have such a family of children you have had to be father and mother both as it were
Completed

now they have all got up and doing well able and willing to take care of themselves and you too if you need. it is a bad feeling to be helpless and dependent on others but that is what we must all come to sooner or later. my sickness and lameness has allways been short as yet and I have allways been taken good care of 
Hannahs health is not very good but she works all the time the children are rather slender Susan is 3 years old just such a lively nervous thing as Abby used to be. I went over the river last Summer saw Beldin Ardelia and Josephs children had a fine visit. Ardelia has got a real good convenient house with Mr. P look as if he was most wore out I dont think he will live many years She is a fine woman has a pretty family I suppose Abby Jerusha and Caroline are all well married. old Mr. Goldsbury is quite feeble Aunt Hasleline has got back lives with Mr Freed Mrs Russell and Edward Mayo and wife have been to see her. they say she looks just as she did 8 years ago Mrs. Russell made me a good long visit last Summer I have not been there since Esther and I went to Brothers and spent the day before she went away Meriah is keeping School I have not seen joanna lately they say she is quite smart last time I went to meeting I heard Mr Hatch I wish I could write something about matters in this town but to tell the truth I dont know much more about the town than you do. old Mr Brown and wife are on the town She is entirely blind  I hear from you sometimes in a roundabout way but I want you should write me a long letter and let me no something about every one of your children and grandchildren
can I help thinking but what you will see Warwick once more

I am really afraid you cannot read what I have written  I must leave off good bye
                                                                              from your affectionate Sister
              A M                                                                                    Betsey Conant
Completed

Unity, Dec. 1st 1850.

Respected & dear Madam,

                            It has been in my heart for some time past to answer yr kind letter; but I have been wandering about, & knew not where to ask you to direct a reply.
   Having the prospect of tarrying for a while at least in this place, I now write in the hope of hearing fr you or Mrs. Searle or some one else of the gd folks about yr temporal & spiritual welfare & prospects. I have to acknowledge, in addition to yr letter, two pairs of woollen stockings fr the Ladies' Socy, I believe. Such proofs of kind remembrance, I can assure you, are exceedingly pleasant to use, & they will be pleasant to use in another sense, this Winter.
  I feel very anxious to know how those who entertained a hope are prospering. Does Harriet still hold to her hope & give evidence that she has reason for so doing? Has James a hope & a gd. ground for it? How does Mrs. Priest prosper, & how is it with Susan Bunefes? Do you know anything about Miss Sturtevant, & Marshy Drake & Marianne Richards? How is it with John yr Nephew (the family name I most strangely forget) & Mrs. Braydon? There were two Boober girls who were somewhat serious; if you cd give me some information about them, it wd be most thankfully recd. I feel anxious to know how the ways of Zion have prospered since I left Milo, whom you now have laboring among you & what the hopes are that the people will enjoy the stated preaching of the word.
 I desire a kind remembrance to Lucy, her little sister & James Searle, as well as to their Mother, also to the Lees, if they are still in town, the Bunefeses?, the Kimballs etc. as you see them.

Stg Milo                                                                                             J Stevens
Stevens                                                                                              ?
Completed

I shd be glad to know whether the Meetings are better attended than formerly & whether any of those who indulged a hope while I was there or any others, indeed, have been added to any of the chhs.

 Thus you perceive that my heart is full of questions & many I must leave unasked because it is so slow work to ask them by means of pen ink & paper. I have a hard field here, but there is need of labor, & I am very well contented. I preach all the time in the same place, in a neat little Meeting house, capable of seating 300 persons, but it is by no means half filled as a general thing. People are not in the habit of going to meeting here, & the habit is yet to be engendered in them. I trust the Lord will remember us in our low estate, & pour out upon his H Spirit.
  I have met yr son Isaac twice within a few weeks, & rode up with him last Saty fr. Bangor, where I had been making a visit. He appears the same as ever, & I trust will live to make a useful man. You may tell Mrs. Searle, if you please, that she need not be afraid to write me now, for I expect in a few months to be a married man.
    With kind remembrances to inquiring friends, I remain 
                                                                   yrs truly,
                                                                             Charles Temple.

Please let me hear as early as possible for I have for a great while been wishing to hear fr. Milo.
Completed

Warwick Aug 1 1857

Dear Sister

 I will try to write once more but I believe I wrote last and I have nothing Special to write but if I could see you I should find enough to say. we have had some very hot weather this summer but very dull hay weather now there is a great deal of hay out spoiling Mr. C has mowed and done a good deal of work he dont complain but little when the sun shines but I know he suffers a great deal but he thinks he must work my health is very good for one 76 I am very clumsy my joints are very stiff and I have a great many poor nights but I dont have much house work to do no cheese to make just milk enough for butter so I have spun fifty skeins of stocking yarn since the first of july. every thing goes on with me quite easy at home as it allways did but I have a great desire to see my friends and to go to meetting as I used to, but I am do Deaf it dont do much good so I must bring my mind to my condition my eyes are very good dont disturb me sundays so on the whole I think I have much to be thankful for. Harveys health is not good but he works Henry is some better but does not work near all the time Susan and Horace have been to School all summer but they have the name of being very feeble Hannah is better than she was last winter so she works and worries most all the time about something or nothing but on the whole she is a good house keeper takes good care and does all she can to make the family comfortable Esther is well and fat and appears to be happy I have been there once & she has been here once this summer sometimes it is a great while I dont see her it is about as hard for me to get there as for some to get to Boston but I write

Betsy Conant Aug. 1, 1857
Elyria
Completed

I have been to Northfield again with A. Whitney had a good time went with Maria to see Mrs. D She is well but looks poor and old She works hard lets her girls all go off to earn something that boy is about the same old Mr. Parsons had a brother like him that lived to be over 50 and never walked Maria has let the farm I dont much expect they will ever live there again Mr. Russell left a will Fanny lived with him over 20 years and he gave her 5 hundred dollars and his Daughter and Edward and his wife the same and all the rest to William Edwards boy Edward has behaved worse than ever since his father died lay drunk day after day and some think William is about as bad he lives in Boston Mrs. Russells children and his girls pursuaded her to wave the will and get her ? it is in the lawyers hands now and she may not live see the end of it
I had a letter from Barnard last week Saml is better than he was in the winter but Marys helath is poor I suppose he has have getting a long a lone S lives with his uncle White is good and steady they say I hope when you write you will let me no all about your children and grandchildren I want to no all about Almeida and her children  I have thought of you this Summer I think you must have some noise living with five babies but I suppose they all love you and you them  cousin Catherine is able to do her work Nathan has buried his youngest Daughter most 16 Tims wife is crazy but he keeps her rather than go to the poor house with her I hope if you do go to Ohio this fall you will come this way. besure and write how you are going and all about it. how thankful we and every one ought to be that have good affectionate children to lean on I make sad work writing but you must read it if you can and besure and write soon

                                    from your affectionate Sister Betsy Conant

[left-hand side] joanna is very crazy again
Completed

Warwick Nov 9 1857

Betsy Conant
Nov. 9. 1857
Elyria

                      Dear Sister I received your letter sometime ago and will try once more to write to you my health is good for one of my age but I know and feel that I am failing body and mind but I am thankful that I can get up and dress myself alone and do my own work after a fashion and then sit down and knit Socks to sell but I have not so much ambition about work as I used to have
 Mr C. is about as usual does some work but complains a great deal I think he shant live through the winter I think he would be too low spirited sometimes if I did not often tell him how much we have to be thankful for. there has been no Death nor any severe Sickness in our house for more tjam 43 years I think it remarkable. Harvey's health is not good but he works most of the time Hannah is much better than she was last winter She works very hard and would if she had but one to work for and two to help her. Henry has not been well for most a year has a pain in his bowels and back has a relax often. he is now taking some vegetable medicine that Joseph Draper sent him from Greenfield I think he is some better but has not much courage. Susan has been to the high school this fall She is a smart capable girl Horacce Mann is a tall good black eyed boy

I suppose your folks out there do not feel the hard times  but I guess they hear something about them from the paper it seems there never was such a time before I am afraid a great many that have to work for a living will suffer this winter if it is as cold as the two last winters were. but I suppose it is all right people have been very extravagant in dress and living for years and now we need something to humble us & make us feel our dependence
Completed

I lately had a letter from Samuel he and his wife are pretty well now Mary was very sick last Summer but is now teaching their winter school young Sammy was at home 2 or 3 weeks in august quite out of health and discouraged he has lived with his uncle White a good while learned the track has had some wages but Mr W has a great many ups and down he has been doing well sometime but I guess he is now pretty low S is there now but if he is able to work I dont no as he will ever get his pay his father is afraid he will get unsteady and go off to the west he is now twenty years old Samuel says his farm ran out fast while he was gone from it but says the crops were good last year and this except potatoes I hope he will be more contented I think if anyone has a farm and something in the house and barn to eat they ought to be thankful. he says one of his cows will make a pound of butter a day through the summer Esthers health is very good and Mr W says he is well but he looks old and very poor Henry begins to look old has a good many Sick turns I think they all have a good deal of patience with each other and get along very well Mrs. Chamberlain has been there made a long visit She gave E a dress and some other things ad Mrs Childs sent her a dress and ten dollars money which pleased her very much Mrs. Russell has not got though with her law suit I am sorry for what she has done it will break friendship all round - the law of love is better I think that the love of law I am sorry Sister  It has got to go I am fraid She wont tell a Straight story they live in Northfield I thought you was in Milo till you wrote was expecting you along every day I hope if you come back while I live you will come this way and make a long visit with her I wish I could see them it dont seem as if I could I have wrote a long letter and now you must guess it out if you can  give my love to all friends. from your affectionate Sister B Conant
[left-hand side] I did not feel approved? at what you wrote but thought you was 70 years old & perhaps began to fail
